ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Improved my sight-singing, transcription, and music analytic abilities. Thought about issues of race, culture, and authorship in music.
I learned the basics of musical harmony, rhythm/meter, structure in an accessible and inclusive way. I practiced singing and transcription in regular homework assignments.
composition, dictation, transcription, modal analysis, large scale form of music analysis, understanding music in the context of society and examining pedagogy in light of different social groups
I developed a better understanding of how to listen to music for analytical purposes and how to switch back and forth between casual experiencing and said analysis.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having this course online is very difficult because I believe that normally it would involve a lot of singing as a group in person. So while there were some weird things about Zoom, I think Michael did a good job of making it as good as it could have been given the circumstances.

The greatest strength of this course was its approach: it was critical of exclusionary or prescriptive ways that music theory has been taught and accepted in the past, and it used a variety of genres of music throughout the class.

strengths: super well organized and interesting every week. great energy every class to get into material in an intellectual and respectful and also enjoyable way
weaknesses: none/wish we had more sessions!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: singing in class was surprisingly successful despite zoom and lag

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This class will give you a more nuanced understanding of music theory while allowing you to develop your aural skills.

absolutely. granted my experience might be instructor specific, but i had such a wonderful time. it was literally my favorite class of the semester :) very solid learning and playing to strengths of people from different backgrounds - something i worried about as a vocalist with relatively less classical training. largely accessible material and a great time

Yes; for anyone interested in gaining more insight into how music is locally structured and how music is influenced by societal boons and failings or for anyone who simply wants to broaden his/her music exposure I would suggest this course.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: A combination of virtual seminar and virtual lecture. Sessions were recorded and made available asynchronously.
Independent exploration of music through application of new lenses on class preparation assignments and homework.

extras.title:
MUSI 218 01
        Aural Skills for Tonal Music
